awd_titl_txt: TARGETED INFUSION PROJECT: Providing Opportunities to Minority Students in STEM (PrOMiSS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP), through Targeted Infusion Projects, supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Fayetteville State University (FSU) seeks to improve the forensic curriculum and research infrastructure through this project, called "Providing Opportunities to Minority Students in STEM (PrOMiSS)." This project will provide students with hands-on training on state-of-the-art equipment that will improve their evidence-based learning abilities in forensic sub-disciplines. These students will be better prepared for employment in the forensic laboratory and/or other STEM field jobs. Success of this model can then be disseminated to other higher learning institutions, particularly minority-serving institutions. Successful implementation of the program goals holds potential for strengthening the social, economic, and intellectual fabric of the southeastern region of North Carolina and beyond.

The overall intent of PrOMiSS is to improve the forensic curriculum and research infrastructure at FSU. The specific goals are to enrich the forensic curriculum; strengthen forensic laboratories' infrastructure; increase passing rates in STEM courses; maintain specialized Forensic Science Education Programs Accreditation Commission (FEPAC) accreditation; improve students' problem solving ability and critical thinking skills by involving them in STEM research; and improve students' attitude towards STEM education. In achieving its goals, PrOMiSS's impact will increase recruitment and retention, graduation rates, the number of underrepresented minority students in forensic disciplines and other STEM fields, and improve the preparation of students for graduate school. The project's greatest impact will be a reduction in the need for post-employment job training for new hires, while increasing the numbers of trained professionals who will contribute to national and global security.

por.por_cntn:
This Targeted Infusion Project (TIP), entitled "Providing Opportunities to Minority Students in STEM (PrOMiSS)" through the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP), is funded to improve the forensic curriculum and research infrastructure at Fayetteville State University (FSU). It carried six major goals to (1) enrich the forensic curriculum and maintain specialized Forensic Science Education Programs Accreditation Commission (FEPAC) accreditation; (2) strengthen forensic laboratories' infrastructure; (3) improve passing rates by reducing failing numbers of DFW (D: D grade; F: fail the course; W: withdraw from the course) in STEM courses; (4) improve students’ problem-solving ability and critical thinking skills by involving them in STEM research; (5) improve students’ attitude towards STEM education; and (6) increase underrepresented populations in forensic workforce and/or related fields.

The research infrastructure of the Forensic Science program at FSU was modernized, including a comparison microscope, four polarized light microscopes, an AFIX Biometric Identification system, a Live scan system and relevant software packages. These facilities are used for research and education of the program. The Forensic Science Curriculum was strengthened in this project. The curriculum was revised, which was approved by FSU and the Forensic Science Education Programs Accreditation Commission (FEPAC). The enrollment of the Forensic Science program was significantly increased in the project period. The Forensic Science Program maintained the accreditation by FEPAC - Bachelors in Forensic Science with full accreditation. This Forensic Science program at FSU is currently the only Forensic Science program accredited by FEPAC in the state of North Carolina.

This project recruited student tutors for peer mentoring. With the assistance of recruited student peer tutors, the failing rates of DFW (D and F grades and W for withdrawal) of 100-level courses have been reduced, including Biology 150 “Principles of Biology I”, Chemistry 141 “General Chemistry I”, Chemistry 161 “General Chemistry II”, Physics 115 “General Physics I”, and Physics 116 “General Physics II”.

In this project, ten undergraduate students were recruited per year for research training by faculty members. The research training was found to be an effective way to attract students to develop careers in STEM as future leaders in STEM. With the faculty mentoring, students in this project actively secured summer research internships based on merit competitions, including Summer Intern Research at Naval Research Laboratory of the Department of Defense (DoD), Summer Research Program at Army Research Laboratory of DoD, Summer Internship at East Carolina University, and SURF program at National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). This project has produced five students admitted to Ph.D. programs in major research universities, including Johns Hopkins University, Oklahoma State University, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Virginia Tech and Wake Forest University. This project also produced three students admitted to masters’ programs, including North Carolina A&T University, Sam Houston State University, and Winston-Salem State University. Students supported by this project started careers in the STEM fields after graduation from FSU, including IRTA program Postbaccalaureate Fellow at National Institute of Health, Lab Technician with the Archer Daniels Midland Company, Forensic Analyst at Houston Forensic Science Center, Animal Health Technician at US Department of Agriculture (USDA), Engineering Technologist at Duke Energy, Officer at US Army Signal Branch, and Science Teacher at Elizabethtown Middle School.

The undergraduate students and faculty conducted research in four disciples, including Biology, Chemistry, Forensic Science and Materials Science. The research had made outcomes in the topics of pesticides formulation and identification of effectiveness to various species, impacting the agriculture; design and optimization of new recyclable catalytic systems based on transition metals supported carbon materials (e.g. CNTs and graphene) for the large-scale industrial and pharmaceutical applications; identification of human DNA in bugs for forensic investigations; and findings of perovskite nanofibers as a new supercapacitor with unique high capacitance properties, nanoscale luminescent materials for high light yield and fast luminescence properties, and improved performance of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) of oxides through chemical doping for designing low-cost new efficient OER catalysts for generating green energy. The research produced publications in peer-reviewed journals and granted patents by faculty and students.
